subject: Leadership
title: Virtue Ethics and Character
description: A micro-lesson that makes Virtue Ethics and Character usable.

hook.text: Aristotle didn't ask 'what should I do?' He asked 'what kind of person should I be?' That changes everything.

buildup.text: Virtue ethics focuses on character traits: courage, honesty, temperance, justice. Good character leads to good choices.

discovery.text: Aristotle's golden mean: virtues sit between extremes. Courage lies between cowardice and recklessness.

twist.text: Character isn't fixed. It's built through practice. Every ethical choice strengthens the muscle. Shortcuts weaken it.

climax.text: Ask yourself: what would a person I admire do here? Then do that. Virtue is about becoming, not just deciding.

punchline.text: Good decisions come from good character. Build the person, not just the policy.

quiz.question: What does Aristotle's golden mean describe?
options: The average of all ethical theories
Virtues as a balance between two extremes
